Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Leisure by Design: The Impact of the Social Sciences on Mass Leisure in America, 1953-1984

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This dissertation explores the impact of the social sciences upon the human-built environment in the United States from 1950 to 1980; specifically, how spaces of mass leisure, such as tourist destinations and world's fairs, were designed. Designers of these spaces, operating in a newly professionalizing sphere, utilized new methods such as operations research, systems analysis, computer modeling, and the rhetorical mobilization of statistical data in their work. These methods were themselves developed in response to the military problems of World War II and the Cold War. Archival research and where possible interviews with practitioners involved will be carried out with focus on the 1962 Seattle World's Fair; the un-built Miami, FL "INTERAMA" Fair; the 1964-65 New York World's Fair; the 1976 American Bicentennial; and state-wide tourism planning efforts in Massachusetts.

Findings will be presented not just in STS and history of science and technology venues, but at trade association conferences and journals, including those of the Travel and Tourism Research Association, the International Association of Amusement Parks, and the National Recreation and Park Association.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to conduct historical research in Science and Technology Studies that leads to fuller understanding of the settings and impact of social scientific consultants and their expertise on the design of spaces of mass leisure in the post-World War II United States. The instances include the 1962 Seattle World's Fair; the 1964-1965 New York World's Fair; the un-built "Interama" exposition of Miami, FL; planning for the Disney theme parks in Anaheim, CA and central Florida; efforts to establish a comprehensive tourism industry policy at the federal level in the United States in the early 1970s; and tourism planning in Massachusetts during the 1960s. Specifically, this grant funded field work at archival repositories in eight U.S. locations (Boston, MA; Miami, FL; New York, NY; Orlando, FL; San Francisco Bay Area, CA; Seattle, WA; Tallahasse, FL; and Washington, DC) and oral history interviews with individuals who provided insight into specific events and contexts.

This project helps broaden our understanding about how science has shaped the present world, especially broadly applied methods and fields that emerged during and after World War II (for example, operations research and systems analysis). Our historical understanding of the history of American science has tended to focus on the hard sciences and technologies. By moving away from this focus, this project can help expand the public’s understanding of the character and nature of science and its methods. Specifically, it sheds light on the character of expertise, the function of consultants (or "go-betweens"), the meaning of objectivity, and the expansion of quantification in and its impact upon American social life.
